liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Four men aged from 16 to 23 were issued with $962 fines for possessing flares and a 16-year-old male was cautioned for throwing a flare at Melbourne's Federation Square last night. Victoria Police said more than 50 flares were discharged and a number of them were thrown, but there were no reports of injury. Police say they've secured CCTV footage and detectives will investigate. You can read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Four men have been fined over flares at a Melbourne Matildas event

children.content: Four men aged from 16 to 23 were issued with $962 fines for possessing flares and a 16-year-old male was cautioned for throwing a flare at Melbourne's Federation Square last night.
Victoria Police said more than 50 flares were discharged and a number of them were thrown, but there were no reports of injury.
Police say they've secured CCTV footage and detectives will investigate.
You can read more here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former Matildas captain Kate Gill tells ABC News Breakfast that Australian soccer now needs to "focus" its attention on supporting A-League Women, off the back of momentum from the Matildas' inspriring push at the Women's World Cup. "[A-League Women] has been the breeding ground for the quality group of players that have come through into our Matildas team at the moment," she says. "So it's important that pathway keeps thriving and to do that we really need to transform it from a semi-amateur competition to a professional competition, and make sure that those players within that environment are full-time professionals and they are remunerated accordingly. "That is our talent pipeline. So we need to get behind and support that. I am hoping that all these fans that are rusted-on Matildas fans now can translate that enthusiasm and start turning up for our A-League Women's players as well."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former Matildas captain Kate Gill calls for fans to "turn up" for A-League Women's players

props.alt: A woman in a jumper and jacket gives a TV interview on Sydney Harbour

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)
Former Matildas captain Kate Gill tells ABC News Breakfast that
Australian soccer now needs to "focus" its attention on supporting A-League Women
, off the back of momentum from the Matildas' inspriring push at the Women's World Cup.
"[A-League Women] has been the breeding ground for the quality group of players that have come through into our Matildas team at the moment," she says.

"So it's important that pathway keeps thriving and to do that we really need to transform it from a semi-amateur competition to a professional competition, and make sure that those players within that environment are full-time professionals and they are remunerated accordingly.

"That is our talent pipeline. So we need to get behind and support that. I am hoping that all these fans that are rusted-on Matildas fans now can translate that enthusiasm and start turning up for our A-League Women's players as well."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Swimming's governing body says it will debut a new "open category" for transgender swimmers at the World Cup in Berlin in October. Last year, World Aquatics voted to ban transgender athletes from competing in elite women's competitions at major events. World Aquatics says the open category will feature in 50-metre and 100-metre races across all strokes. It says more events could be added.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Open category' added for transgender swimmers at World Cup

children.content: Swimming's governing body says it will debut a new "open category" for transgender swimmers at the
World Cup in Berlin in October.
Last year, World Aquatics
voted to ban transgender athletes
from competing in elite women's competitions at major events.
World Aquatics says the open category will feature in 50-metre and 100-metre races across all strokes.
It says more events could be added.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Our largest energy retailer, Origin Energy has also posted their results this morning, recording a profit of $1.1 billion for the last financial year. It's a return to profitability for the energy company, which reported a loss of $1.4 billion last year. The energy retailer notes that that its underlying earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) for energy markets increased by $637 million to $1.038 billion, and that its electricity profits rose as higher wholesale energy costs were recovered in tariffs and the "optimisation of the energy supply portfolio". The gains also come despite the global energy crunch, which has sent gas and electricity prices higher. It also forecasts more growth in the coming financial year, before moderating in the 2025 financial year. Origin will pay shareholders a fully-franked final dividend of 20 cents per share .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Origin Energy profits hit $1.1 billion

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Telstra's full-year results are just out and its a big year for Australia's dominant telco, with net profit up 13.1% to $2.05 billion. Profit attributable to Telstra equity holders was up 14.2% to $1.93 billion. The rise in profit was based on a 5.4% increase in total income to $23.2 billion. "We remain disciplined on reducing our costs, particularly considering the external economic environment," said Telstra's CEO Vicki Brady. Ms Brady said her priority was to continue to improve customer experience and further reduce complaints to the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman, which the company said fell by more than a third on the previous year. Telstra also revealed that its current plan is to retain ownership of its infrastructure business, InfraCo Fixed, "for at least the medium term" after it was structurally separated out from the rest of the firm earlier this year, meaning a sale or public share float is off the table for now. The telco was cautious in its guidance, predicting total income should be slightly higher than current levels but could be lower ($22.8 to $24.8 billion), while underlying profits before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) of $8.2-8.4 billion would be slightly higher than this year's $8 billion result. "While our cost reduction ambition is being challenged by high inflation, we still expect to achieve the large majority of this by financial year 2025," added Ms Brady. The company will pay a fully-franked final dividend of 8.5 cents per share bringing total dividends for the year to 17 cents, slightly up on last year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Telstra profit jumps 13 per cent, passes $2b

net profit up 13.1% to $2.05 billion
Profit attributable to Telstra equity holders was up 14.2% to $1.93 billion.
The rise in profit was based on a
5.4% increase in total income to $23.2 billion
"We remain disciplined on reducing our costs, particularly considering the external economic environment," said Telstra's CEO Vicki Brady.

Ms Brady said her priority was to continue to improve customer experience and further reduce complaints to the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman, which the company said fell by more than a third on the previous year.
Telstra also revealed that its current plan is to
retain ownership of its infrastructure business, InfraCo Fixed, "for at least the medium term"
after it was structurally separated out from the rest of the firm earlier this year, meaning a sale or public share float is off the table for now.
The telco was
cautious in its guidance

, predicting total income should be slightly higher than current levels but could be lower ($22.8 to $24.8 billion), while underlying profits before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) of $8.2-8.4 billion would be slightly higher than this year's $8 billion result.
"While our cost reduction ambition is being challenged by high inflation, we still expect to achieve the large majority of this by financial year 2025," added Ms Brady.
The company will pay a
fully-franked final dividend of 8.5 cents per share
bringing total dividends for the year to 17 cents, slightly up on last year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Oil prices have once again taken a hit overnight, with brent crude falling by 1.9% to come in at $US83.29 a barrel. That's despite a huge drawdown on the US's stocks of crude, tightening supply, over concerns about China's faltering economy. West Texas crude also fell to $US75.35, and is the lowest level for both benchmarks in almost two weeks. It comes after the US's inventories of crude oil fell by close to 6 million barrels last week, thanks to strong exports and increased run rates by refiners. But despite an increase in crude production, those inventories are still falling, and is a sign that refiners are struggling to keep up with demand.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Oil price falls below $US84 a barrel despite shrinking stockpile
